something interesting is happening here; for utility there is a constraint on what input is interpreted so that the scribble becomes an 8 even though the true information was a long curvy line. the useful information 8 erases the true information long curvy line in a sort of computing bias.. we only need to be able to see numbers 1 through 9 so we don't need to compute everything else. Similarly to our real eyes and brains that only "see" certain wavelengths of light and compute relevant information, particularly information that will have a fitness payoff for our survival and evolution.   in this demonstration we can see how information will be omitted or even changed completely for convenience in the complex computing system of our brains

I've often had the same thought in regards to "communities" forming some kind of higher level entity. You can blow your own mind in reverse -- it is known that if you split a brain into their natural halves by severing the corpus collosum between them, you can survive and continue to function. If you were able to take one half of that brain and put it into a separate body, what would you have? Two "you's"? So the two half "you's" form a greater entity of you -- perhaps this is you when you're arguing with yourself as to what course of action to take.

So then if you put several brains together working on a problem, do you create a "higher level" entity which the individual brains are not aware of, the way individual neurons are not really aware of the greater total brain?

So then does congress and the rest of the people of the US create some kind of super-entity that we are not aware of? And you can argue that we do as the rest of the world perceives the US to be a rather war-like nation. Few of us are individually, but we certainly act this way as a nation. China as a nation has a personality. Italy does. France does. Germany does.

Emergence is a trippy concept.

I had a thought while watching this: so, in this experiment they made one human be a single neuron that just flys a flag, or not. Now that is cool, but if you want to make a more complex brain you totally could make one human have two flags, lets say one of them red and one blue. This way one human can look for more signals and either fly a red or a blue flag, then some neurons behind him look for red and some for blue flags. This way we can make a much more complex brain from way less people, because a man isnt just a dumb thing that either does or does not do something, a man can be a much more complicated and better neuron. It would be very interesting to see this experimend be redone with theese adjustments and maybe even more people. If an experiment like this is done, it can prove that human neurons are able to evolve to be much more complex without increasing their number. LOL, here I thought they were going to use back propagation ( "learn" ) on the brain and people were just going to give up.


back propagation for this brain:


Give the retinal people their squares, have them fire, then have everyone guess if they are suppose to fire or not based on who they are suppose to look at. Then, start from the IT. Ask them why they fired or didn't. If they came up with the correct answer (on when their number was drawn or off when it wasn't), then pat them on the back. If they came up with the wrong answer, tell them they (probably) should have had the opposite result on what they saw.


Then go to V4. Look at how each V4 person influenced the people of IT. If they generally caused IT to get the right answers, pat them on the back. If they generally caused wrong answers, tell them they (probably) should have had the opposite result based on what they saw.


Rinse repeat for each layer. After doing this process a few hundred times the brain might be able to identify some numbers


However, one reason back propagation here is far more messy than in computational neural networks is because when done in a computer, the "neurons" don't have to be strictly on or off, but can send any decimal number of strength, so individuals would be able to indicate when they are less confident and not skew actual processing that is happening.

The last try actually didn't work. There was no 8 in the image, so none should have fired in the final row ! I think the reason it fired an eight is that it didn't see wether each pixel was part of a vertical line or a horizontal line. Michael drew horizontal line on most pixel, then the V2 layer saw vertical lines in it.
I believe with much more neurons it could be made possible to get it right. Each of the 16 pixel is divided into 9 smaller pixels, so you get 144 people on the first layer. With the same drawing he drew before, there would be gaps between the 4 horizontal lines, so no vertical line could be seen out of it. Then next step is for the brain to understand what is it, since it knows it isn't a number. So you'd need even more layers, able to process more shapes.

This was great.  You know what would be cool?  A long-term project like this managed through an app/website.  Users sign up and each "round" assigns a new role to each user.  When a round starts, the Retina users get emails/notifications saying "you're up" and they login, process their input, and determine "fire" or "not fire".  Once all (or a sufficient subset) of users from the retina fire, the next level (V1) of users are notified with their pertinent ruleset.  A single 'round' can take as long as it needs to as long as the rate of responses is above a certain threshold.  If that threshold drops below the lower limit, the "round" is failed and the users who did not respond in a timely manner receive a "potentially damaged neuron" mark.  Once a user receives X amount of PDN marks, their account is paused or terminated (only working neurons allowed in this game but, of course, users can request re-admittance after a time).  The scale/scope of the 'image' or input can be function of the neuron pool volume so as more people join, more complex 'images' can be processed -- color, etc.

We still don't understand the nature of certain forms of energy like dark matter, and we have no concept of how things move on large scales and in time frames that seem impossible to us, but a blink to a collection of galaxies. It's amazing to see all of the individual parts of the body building up and up and up to make something so spectacular. If you put a soup of 3 trillion cells of varying types and makeups into a big pot and stirred it, I doubt that they would invent calculus. But when they are allowed to work cohesively, these 3 trillion individual cells, despite still functioning relatively independent, can become something so amazing.


If you see a human, and you go down one layer, you'll find a bunch of organ systems working together to make it function, like run, think, digest, and breathe. If you go down deeper, you'll see layers and layers of tissue, laid on top of one another in such a way that they can all work together. If you go down deeper, you'll find tons of cells, all just doing their jig of making energy and dividing into more of themselves. If you go deeper, you'll find organelles, all having a unique function to allow that cell to divide. If you go deeper, you'll see strings of atoms that tell that cell what to do and how to make what when. If you go deeper, you'll see a collection of varying atoms, all vibrating really fast and moving around. If you go deeper, you'll see groups of three quarks that are just happy to be here. The smaller you go, the less aware the parts are, but all of them combine to create a cohesive unit we call Humanity.
